content:
ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ THE GUYANA BRIEF ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾Your 5-Minute Weekend News Circus
Saturday, January 10, 2026
Sponsored by: Contractors Who Can't See 69,000-Volt Lines
ğŸ“Š WEEKEND QUICK STATS Mohamed Self-Pity Level: ğŸ’¯ MAXIMUM
Vloggers Regretting Guyana Visit: 2/2
National Grid Near-Death Experiences: ğŸ”¥ Another One
Opposition Pulse Check: âš°ï¸ Flatline
Houses To Build Per Day: 22 ğŸ˜‚
ğŸ­ STORY #1: THE MOHAMEDS PRESENT: “VICTIM: THE MUSICAL” Opening Scene: Nazar Mohamed, fresh from discovering that being indicted for fraud is “oppression,” has penned a heartfelt op-ed. Think Les MisÃ©rables, but the convict owns bulletproof cars.
What The Papers Said:
KAIETEUR: Gave him the entire front page. "THIS IS NOT LAW, THIS IS OPPRESSION!" (Also Kaieteur: sold more papers that day)
CHRONICLE: "Prosecution wants earlier date" (translation: Florida is TIRED)
STABROEK: Mysteriously silent (lawyers probably said "don't touch this")
GUYANA TIMES: "Case adjourned to February 5" (just the facts, ma'am)
The Plot Twist: While Mohamed writes 2,000 words about persecution, the prosecution is literally begging: “Can we PLEASE do this sooner?” and the defense lawyers are like “Sorry, we’re washing our hair until February.”
Mohamed’s Grievances Include:
Insurance companies won’t cover his bulletproof vehicles anymore (the AUDACITY) GRA employees who helped him are being arrested (for helping him commit fraud, but details!) His lands are being “illegally occupied” (by people who probably have actual legal papers) The government is using “political influence” (from the guy indicted for using business influence) The Persecution-O-Meter:
98% Victim / 2% ConsequencesActual Persecution: Being asked to answer fraud charges
Mohamed's Persecution: Everything including gravity
Next Court Date: February 5 (unless they file to delay the delay)
âš¡ STORY #2: CONTRACTOR DISCOVERS ELECTRICITY THE HARD WAY Breaking: RZND Concrete Company decided to play “How Close Can We Get to 69,000 Volts Before Someone Arrests Us?”
Spoiler Alert: Not very close!
The Setup:
GPL has a 69,000-volt transmission line This line connects Sophia to Good Hope (keeps Regions 4 & 5 from becoming candlelit dinner zones) Contractor extends concrete pump DIRECTLY OVER IT GPL: “ARE YOU TRYING TO KILL US ALL?!” GPL’s Strongly Worded Letter:
â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•—â•‘ âš ï¸ NATIONAL EMERGENCY ALERT âš ï¸ â•‘â•‘ â•‘â•‘ CONTRACTOR: Actively courting death â•‘â•‘ VOLTAGE: 69,000 (crispy level) â•‘â•‘ REGIONS AFFECTED: Everyone â•‘â•‘ STATUS: Contractor detained â•‘â•‘ â•‘â•‘ "One miscalculation could have â•‘â•‘ triggered MAJOR SYSTEM FAILURE" â•‘â•‘ â•‘â•‘ TRANSLATION: Y'all almost blacked â•‘â•‘ out the entire coast because someone â•‘â•‘ can't see giant power lines â•‘â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•Best Part: This is the SECOND time in THREE MONTHS! Last time, someone tried to move a police station and hit power lines.
New Guyana Construction Checklist:
Get construction permit Check for underground utilities Check for OVERHEAD UTILITIES (we keep forgetting this one!) Maybe ask “will this plunge 100,000 people into darkness?” Call GPL at 226-2600 (this number is in the press release for a reason!) ğŸ“ˆ STORY #3: 2025 STATISTICS - A HORROR STORY Murders: â¬†ï¸ UP 11% (130 people dead)
Road Deaths: â¬†ï¸ UP 6% (137 people dead)
Total Accidents: â¬‡ï¸ DOWN 10%
Wait… WHAT?
GPF: "Great news! Accidents are DOWN!"
Also GPF: "Bad news! Deaths are UP!"
Us: "How does that evenâ€”"
GPF: "We're as confused as you are."
World Bank: "Your 15 deaths per 100,000 is UNACCEPTABLY HIGH"
Government: "We'll get it to 50 total by 2030!"
Current Trajectory: Going from 137 to 50... by adding more each year? Bold strategy!
Translation: We’re having FEWER crashes, but when we crash, we’re doing it PROFESSIONALLY. Quality over quantity, apparently.
Government’s Road Safety Plan:
Install cameras âœ“ Issue e-tickets âœ“ Hope really hard âœ“ Actually fix roads âŒ Driver education âŒ ğŸ¬ STORY #4: GUYANA TOURISM PRESENTS: “DON’T FILM THIS” Act 1: The British Vlogger
Ellis Riding arrives in Georgetown with a camera. Films garbage dumps, street people, and dangerous areas. Says Guyana is “one of the most Third World places” he’s seen.
Chronicle’s Response: Publishes 1,000-word column calling him a “10th-rate British foot-traveller” with “rotten mentality” who’s “probably paid by the opposition.”
Chronicle’s Defense: “It’s dangerous in Miami too!” (This is the new national slogan apparently)
Act 2: The French Vlogger
Antony D’Oliveira is filming. Vendor Quacy McKay doesn’t want to be filmed. Logical response? SLAP HIM IN THE BACK OF THE HEAD.
McKay’s Court Explanation: “I was just trying to move the camera!”
Judge: “Sir, that’s not how cameras work.”
Bail: ,000
Tourism Guyana’s New Slogan Ideas:
ğŸ¥ UPDATED TOURISM WARNINGSFilm something nice: You're a hero! Come back soon!
Film reality: Chronicle will question your ancestry
Film a vendor: That's a slappin'
Complain: "But Miami though!"
Guyana: Come for the oil, leave with assault charges!
ğŸ—ï¸ STORY #5: VP ANNOUNCES INFINITY HOUSES The Grand Plan: Build 40,000 houses in 5 years!
The Math They Should’ve Done:
40,000 houses Ã· 5 years = 8,000/year
8,000 Ã· 365 days = 22 HOUSES PER DAY
22 houses Ã· 24 hours = ONE HOUSE EVERY 65 MINUTES
AROUND THE CLOCK. NO BREAKS. NO WEEKENDS. FOR FIVE YEARS.
One Letter Writer’s Take:
"This is ludicrous and comical... tantamount to putting 10 pounds grocery in a 5-pound bag"
Problems He Identified:
No zoning laws (houses wherever!)No building codes (walls optional!)No inspections (safety is a social construct!)The dreaded 4 S's: Sliding, Slipping, Sagging, SinkingLand titles take forever and cost a fortunePoor roads, garbage everywhere, water scarceHis Verdict: "Another colossal failure in the making"
Previous Government “Trust Me Bro” Projects:
âŒ Amaila Falls Hydropower (fell through) âŒ Surendra Hospital (still not sure what happened) âŒ Skeldon Sugar Factory (sweet disaster) ğŸ² 40,000 Houses (place your bets now!) ğŸ’¡ STORY #6: THE ELECTRICITY PROMISE ENTERS THE WITNESS PROTECTION PROGRAM October 2024: “I promise to cut electricity by 50% before end of 2025!” - President Ali
January 2026: crickets
Current Situation:
Month 1 Bill: ,000
Month 2 Bill (same usage): ,000
GPL Explanation: Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯
Citizens: "Can you explain the difference?"
GPL: *currently dealing with contractors trying to blow up transmission lines*
President's Promise: Last seen heading to the airport with a fake mustache
May 2025 Quote: “Infrastructure transformation beyond anyone’s wildest imagination!”
January 2026 Reality: Bills still wildly unpredictable, Heroes Highway needs repairs after 2 years, and we almost lost power because someone extended a concrete pump.
Wildest Imagination Status: Confirmed.
ğŸ¤« STORY #7: HAS ANYONE SEEN THE OPPOSITION? Last Spotted: Norton gave a press conference about deportees
Current Status: MISSING
Kaieteur’s Editorial: “Calling the opposition, calling the opposition”
ğŸš¨ MISSING PERSON ALERT ğŸš¨
NAME: The Opposition
LAST SEEN: Making a statement about something
DESCRIPTION: Should be loud and oppositional
CURRENT BEHAVIOR: Suspiciously quiet
IF FOUND: Please remind them about:
Electricity bills still high22 houses per day is impossibleMurders up 11%Road deaths increasingHeroes Highway already needs fixingREWARD: A functioning democracy
Kaieteur’s Savage Quote: “It is almost as if the opposition in Guyana is in [the PPP’s] fold, under its control”
Ouch.
ğŸŒŸ ACTUAL GOOD NEWS: HINTERLAND GETS CONNECTED Real Talk: Aishalton airstrip commissioned! This is genuinely awesome!
What It Means:
Communities no longer isolated Lower transport costs Better healthcare access Educational opportunities Economic development Jags Aviation: Already lowering fares!
Chronicle Headline: “From isolation to integration” (Actually inspiring! Who wrote this?)
Government: Actually delivering on hinterland development.
Us: Pleasantly surprised! Do more of this, less of the 22-houses-per-day promises!
ğŸ“° TODAY’S LESSONS Being indicted for fraud is "oppression" (write that down)69,000 volts < concrete pump placement priorityFewer crashes + more deaths = Guyana mathTourists with cameras = hostiles22 houses/day = totally doable (if you're high)Electricity promises have expiration datesOpposition.exe has stopped respondingHinterland development is actually happening! ğŸ‰ğŸ”® MONDAY’S PREDICTIONS ğŸ”¹ Mohameds file 47-page motion explaining how prosecution wanting an earlier date proves persecution
ğŸ”¹ Another contractor "forgets" about critical infrastructure (bingo anyone?)
ğŸ”¹ GPL updates slogan to "Keeping the lights on DESPITE contractors"
ğŸ”¹ Opposition spotted, immediately pretends to be mannequin
ğŸ”¹ VP doubles down: "Actually, 80,000 houses in 2.5 years"
ğŸ”¹ Chronicle publishes op-ed: "Why Monday is actually the opposition's fault"
ğŸ’­ WEEKEND WISDOM In a country where a man indicted for fraud writes op-eds about oppression while contractors treat power lines like suggestions and the government promises to build one house every 65 minutes for five straight years…
At least we’re building airstrips and the lights are still on.
Barely.
Stay safe, Guyana. And contractors? FOR THE LOVE OF GPL, CALL BEFORE YOU BUILD! ğŸ“
The Guyana Brief: Your daily dose of “wait, that actually happened?” ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾
All stories real. All outrage justified. All satire absolutely necessary.
summary:

Saturday, January 10, 2026

content:
About The Daily Laugh ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ Welcome to The Daily Laugh - your daily satirical roundup of Guyana’s four major newspapers.
What We Do We read Stabroek News, Kaieteur News, Chronicle, and Guyana Times every day, then write funny commentary about the headlines. We’re not real journalists - we’re satirists who care about Guyana enough to mock its problems.
Meet CARIBSTAR Your editor and chief troublemaker. Strong opinions, questionable judgment, excellent coffee tolerance.
Contact Questions? Complaints? Want to tell us we’re hilarious or terrible? Drop us a line.
Email: caribbeandailybrief@gmail.com
This is satire. See our Legal Disclaimer for details.

This Is Satire All content on The Daily Laugh is satirical commentary on Guyana news. We’re not journalists - we’re satirists.
Fair Use & Copyright We summarize news from Guyana’s four major newspapers under fair use principles:
We don’t republish full articles We add substantial original commentary We transform content into satire We attribute sources Not Defamation Our satire focuses on:
Public officials and their conduct Matters of public interest Political controversies Public policy We don’t target private citizens or make false accusations.
No Professional Advice This blog doesn’t provide legal, financial, or medical advice. Consult professionals for serious matters.
Contact Questions or complaints? Contact us at: caribbeandailybrief@gmail.com
Bottom Line: We’re satirists exercising free speech to comment on Guyana’s public affairs. We respect copyright and avoid defamation.

title: Legal Disclaimer

content:
ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ THE DAILY LAUGH ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾Your 5-Minute Guyana News Digest
Sponsored by: Strong Coffee & Questionable Life Choices
ğŸ­ BREAKING: MADURO GETS THE ULTIMATE SURPRISE PARTY ğŸ“Š QUICK STATS:
Operation Speed: Faster than DoorDash
Caribbean Group Chat Status: ğŸ”¥ Going Wild
Guyana's Official Response: Diplomatically ThrilledY’all, the Americans just Uber-kidnapped an entire president. Not even DoorDash is that efficient.
What Happened: Trump sent the boys to Venezuela like it was a Black Friday sale at Courts. Operation resulted in NicolÃ¡s Maduro getting the express trip to New York he DEFINITELY didn’t book on Travelocity.
ğŸ—£ï¸ WHAT THE PAPERS SAID:
ğŸ“° Stabroek News: "We must consider the geopolitical implications..."
ğŸ“° Kaieteur News: "MADURO GRABBED! WE BEEN TELLING Y'ALL!"
ğŸ“° Chronicle: "President Ali Says Things. Government Does Stuff. Everything Fine."
ğŸ“° Guyana Times: "Anyway, here's a story about motorsports and a beauty pageant."
Guyana’s Response: President Ali is doing that Caribbean thing where you’re simultaneously thrilled, terrified, and trying not to laugh. He commended Trump which is like thanking the bouncer for removing your drunk ex from the party.
Real Talk: Guyana just watched its annoying neighbor get arrested on COPS: International Edition. Live. In real time. While the whole Caribbean group chat was going absolutely wild.
The Awkward Part: Now Guyana has to pretend they’re not THRILLED about this. Because diplomacy. And international relations. And the fact that they share a border with a country that just got regime-changed via air strike.
ğŸ’° THE MOHAMEDS: AMERICA’S MOST WANTED âš–ï¸ THE MOHAMED LEGAL SAGA TRACKER âš–ï¸
Legal Strategies Used: 80%Courts Appealed To: ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ›ï¸ (and counting)
Florida's Response: *uses full name*
This father-son duo is having the kind of week that makes you reconsider all your life choices.
The Situation: The Mohameds are fighting extradition to Florida harder than your auntie fights for the last piece of black cake at Christmas. Their legal strategy appears to be “The Mohameds are NOT going anywhere!” which is NOT how extradition treaties work.
BREAKING NEWS TICKER
ğŸš¨ Court says NO â†’ Lawyers say APPEAL â†’ Repeat Loop #4 ğŸš¨
Their Lawyers Said: “We are confident this case will be dismissed.”
The Court Said: “No.”
Their Lawyers Said: “Well, we’re appealing.”
Everyone Else: “Of course you are.”
Kaieteur’s Coverage: They’ve written more about the Mohameds than the Mohameds’ mothers did in baby books. At this point, Kaieteur News could publish a Mohameds encyclopedia.
The Pattern: Court says yes, Lawyers say no, Appeal filed, Repeat. They’re currently on loop 4.
Florida’s Patience Level: Approaching zero. The US Attorney’s office has started sending strongly worded letters, which in legal terms is like your mom using your full name.
ğŸ›£ï¸ HEROES HIGHWAY: A LOVE STORY GONE WRONG âš ï¸ INFRASTRUCTURE SPEED-RUN CHALLENGE âš ï¸
Built:December 2023 (concrete)Lasted:13 MONTHSExpected Lifespan:20-30 yearsAchievement:World Record FailureDecember 2023: Government unveils shiny new concrete highway
January 2025: Ministry announces asphalt overlay project
Let’s Do The Math: That’s 13 months. The highway lasted about as long as a New Year’s resolution.
Translation: They built a highway with concrete. Premium concrete. It lasted barely over a year. Now they want to cover it with asphalt.
ğŸ“‹ HOW INFRASTRUCTURE WORKS:
Elsewhere: Plan â†’ Build â†’ Maintain â†’ Use for decades âœ“
In Guyana: Plan (maybe) â†’ Build â†’ Celebrate â†’ Break â†’ Act surprised â†’ Announce solutions â†’ Repeat ğŸ”„
This is like:
Buying a Tesla and gluing a bicycle on top Ordering premium steak and covering it with ketchup Building a mansion and putting up wallpaper to hide the cracks Stabroek News (Being Polite): “Questions have been raised about whether sound decisions are being made…”
Us (Not Being Polite): Y’ALL BUILT A HIGHWAY WRONG.
What Actually Happened: Someone made a decision. That decision was wrong. That wrongness cost millions. Now another decision will cost more millions to fix the first wrong decision.
Engineering 101: Concrete highways should last 20-30 years. Heroes Highway speedran that timeline like it was going for a world record.
ğŸ“± DIGITAL SCHOOL: WHEN ZOOM FINALLY CAME TO GUYANA ğŸ“ DIGITAL SCHOOL SUCCESS METRICS ğŸ“
âœ“ Students logged into Zoomâœ“ Internet didn't crashâœ“ Teachers troubleshot for 45 minutesâœ“ Taught for 10 minutesâ†’ ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED!The Ministry of Education is THRILLED to announce that students successfully… logged into Zoom.
Let That Sink In: The achievement isn’t the lesson. The achievement isn’t the teaching. The achievement is that THE INTERNET DIDN’T CRASH.
Participating Schools: Dora Secondary, St. Cuthbert’s Secondary, Kwakwani Secondary, Linden Foundation Secondary, Anna Regina Secondary.
ğŸ† ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED:
Guyana Internet Works For 20 Minutes!
Parent’s Perspective: “So my data plan is now a school supply?”
Teacher’s Perspective: “I spent 45 minutes troubleshooting connectivity and 10 minutes teaching.”
Government’s Perspective: “DIGITAL TRANSFORMATION! PROGRESS!”
Reality Check: Other countries have been doing this since 2020. We’re celebrating in 2026 that we successfully used Zoom. The app your grandmother figured out during COVID.
ğŸŒ¾ RICE FARMERS GET 2.1 BILLION ğŸ’¸ THE FLOOD RELIEF CYCLE ğŸ’¸
1ï¸âƒ£ Build drainage systems
2ï¸âƒ£ Don't maintain them
3ï¸âƒ£ Flooding happens
4ï¸âƒ£ Act surprised
5ï¸âƒ£ Give out money
6ï¸âƒ£ Repeat next year ğŸ”„
Agriculture Minister Mustapha is touring the country handing out checks like Oprah’s Guyanese cousin.
The Official Story: “Government assistance initiative”
The Real Story: “Remember when y’all flooded twice? Here’s some money. Sorry about that.”
Black Bush Polder Residents: “Our crops are still underwater but okay, thanks.”
May 2024: Flooding
December 2024: More flooding
January 2025: Money for the flooding
What Farmers Actually Need: Working drainage, flood prevention, infrastructure maintenance, maybe some oil money?
What Farmers Got: Checks after damage is done, photo op with minister, promises of improvement.
ğŸ¯ YOUR DAILY RECAP ğŸ“ WHAT WE LEARNED:
Trump moves faster than Guyana contractorsThe Mohameds discovered infinite appeals glitchConcrete highways are temporaryWorking Wi-Fi is a national achievementFlood relief works better as preventionğŸ”® TOMORROW'S FORECAST:
â˜ï¸ 100% chance of Mohamed headlines
ğŸŒ§ï¸ 80% chance of ministry denials
â›ˆï¸ 60% chance of infrastructure announcements
ğŸŒ©ï¸ 40% chance infrastructure breaks within a year
This is satirical commentary protected under Guyana's fair use provisions. See our Legal Disclaimer.
Â© 2026 The Daily Laugh | Not actual news, just actual laughs ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ğŸ˜‚

Problems He Identified:
No zoning laws (houses wherever!)No building codes (walls optional!)No inspections (safety is a social construct!)The dreaded 4 S's: Sliding, Slipping, Sagging, SinkingLand titles take forever and cost a fortunePoor roads, garbage everywhere, water scarceHis Verdict: "Another colossal failure in the making"
Previous Government “Trust Me Bro” Projects:
âŒ Amaila Falls Hydropower (fell through) âŒ Surendra Hospital (still not sure what happened) âŒ Skeldon Sugar Factory (sweet disaster) ğŸ² 40,000 Houses (place your bets now!) ğŸ’¡ STORY #6: THE ELECTRICITY PROMISE ENTERS THE WITNESS PROTECTION PROGRAM October 2024: “I promise to cut electricity by 50% before end of 2025!” - President Ali
January 2026: crickets
Current Situation:
Month 1 Bill: ,000
Month 2 Bill (same usage): ,000
GPL Explanation: Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯
Citizens: "Can you explain the difference?"
GPL: *currently dealing with contractors trying to blow up transmission lines*
President's Promise: Last seen heading to the airport with a fake mustache
May 2025 Quote: “Infrastructure transformation beyond anyone’s wildest imagination!”
January 2026 Reality: Bills still wildly unpredictable, Heroes Highway needs repairs after 2 years, and we almost lost power because someone extended a concrete pump.
Wildest Imagination Status: Confirmed.
ğŸ¤« STORY #7: HAS ANYONE SEEN THE OPPOSITION? Last Spotted: Norton gave a press conference about deportees
Current Status: MISSING
Kaieteur’s Editorial: “Calling the opposition, calling the opposition”
ğŸš¨ MISSING PERSON ALERT ğŸš¨
NAME: The Opposition
LAST SEEN: Making a statement about something
DESCRIPTION: Should be loud and oppositional
CURRENT BEHAVIOR: Suspiciously quiet
IF FOUND: Please remind them about:
Electricity bills still high22 houses per day is impossibleMurders up 11%Road deaths increasingHeroes Highway already needs fixingREWARD: A functioning democracy
Kaieteur’s Savage Quote: “It is almost as if the opposition in Guyana is in [the PPP’s] fold, under its control”
Ouch.
ğŸŒŸ ACTUAL GOOD NEWS: HINTERLAND GETS CONNECTED Real Talk: Aishalton airstrip commissioned! This is genuinely awesome!
What It Means:
Communities no longer isolated Lower transport costs Better healthcare access Educational opportunities Economic development Jags Aviation: Already lowering fares!
Chronicle Headline: “From isolation to integration” (Actually inspiring! Who wrote this?)
Government: Actually delivering on hinterland development.
Us: Pleasantly surprised! Do more of this, less of the 22-houses-per-day promises!
ğŸ“° TODAY’S LESSONS Being indicted for fraud is "oppression" (write that down)69,000 volts < concrete pump placement priorityFewer crashes + more deaths = Guyana mathTourists with cameras = hostiles22 houses/day = totally doable (if you're high)Electricity promises have expiration datesOpposition.exe has stopped respondingHinterland development is actually happening! ğŸ‰ğŸ”® MONDAY’S PREDICTIONS ğŸ”¹ Mohameds file 47-page motion explaining how prosecution wanting an earlier date proves persecution
ğŸ”¹ Another contractor "forgets" about critical infrastructure (bingo anyone?)
ğŸ”¹ GPL updates slogan to "Keeping the lights on DESPITE contractors"
ğŸ”¹ Opposition spotted, immediately pretends to be mannequin
ğŸ”¹ VP doubles down: "Actually, 80,000 houses in 2.5 years"
ğŸ”¹ Chronicle publishes op-ed: "Why Monday is actually the opposition's fault"
ğŸ’­ WEEKEND WISDOM In a country where a man indicted for fraud writes op-eds about oppression while contractors treat power lines like suggestions and the government promises to build one house every 65 minutes for five straight years…
At least we’re building airstrips and the lights are still on.
Barely.
Stay safe, Guyana. And contractors? FOR THE LOVE OF GPL, CALL BEFORE YOU BUILD! ğŸ“
The Guyana Brief: Your daily dose of “wait, that actually happened?” ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾
All stories real. All outrage justified. All satire absolutely necessary.

content:
ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ THE DAILY LAUGH ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ Your 5-Minute Guyana News Digest
Friday, January 9, 2026
Sponsored by: Bridge Repair Funds (Just Kidding, Those Don't Exist)
ğŸ“¦ BREAKING: GUYANA VOLUNTEERS AS AMERICA’S STORAGE UNIT ğŸ“Š QUICK STATS:
Countries Involved: 3+ (none of them asked)
Opposition Anger Level: ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥
Kaieteur News Caps Lock: MAXIMUM In the wildest plot twist since the 2020 elections, Guyana is in “productive discussions” with the United States about accepting third-country nationals.
Let That Sink In: America wants to deport people from OTHER countries to Guyana. Not Americans. Not even people who’ve ever BEEN to Guyana. Just random third-country nationals that America doesn’t want.
The Papers’ Reactions:
ğŸ“° Stabroek News: "Questions raised about constitutional implications..." (polite panic)
ğŸ“° Kaieteur News: "THE PEOPLE MUST KNOW!" (not polite at all)
ğŸ“° Chronicle: "President Ali Praised By US!" (completely different story)
ğŸ“° Guyana Times: "Ten delegates ready for pageant!" (what deportees?)
The Opposition’s Take: WIN and Forward Guyana are furious, calling it unconstitutional. The government’s defense? “But you guys made backroom deals too!” Everyone conveniently forgets details.
Meanwhile: Guyana watched Trump literally invade Venezuela, extract Maduro, and announce “we’re running this country now.” Ali’s response: “We support regional security efforts!” Translation: Please don’t invade us next.
âš–ï¸ THE MOHAMEDS: APPEAL SEASON CONTINUES âš–ï¸ THE MOHAMED APPEAL-O-METER âš–ï¸
Appeals Filed: 95% Courts Remaining: ğŸ¤” (Maybe 1?)
Florida's Patience: â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘â–‘ 0%
The father-son gold trading duo filed YET ANOTHER appeal to the Full Court. Their legal strategy is simple: if at first you don’t succeed, appeal, appeal, appeal again.
Latest Development: Prosecution tried to get an earlier hearing date than February 5. Defense said no. Government circles reportedly “consternated.” Parliament can’t convene until this is resolved because Azruddin Mohamed is the Opposition Leader-elect.
Kaieteur News: Has written 4,000+ articles on this saga. They’ve turned it into a soap opera: Days of Our Extraditions.
ğŸŒ‰ HIGH STREET BRIDGE JOINS THE INFRASTRUCTURE HALL OF SHAME âš ï¸ INFRASTRUCTURE FAILURE ALERT âš ï¸
Status: CRACKED & SINKING
Weight Limit: 10 tonnes (basically useless)
Surprise Level: 0% (we all saw this coming)
The High Street bridge between Lamaha and Cowan Streets is cracked and sinking. New weight limit: 10 tonnes. The bridge designed to handle traffic can no longer handle traffic.
How Infrastructure Works:
Elsewhere: Plan â†’ Build â†’ Maintain â†’ Use for decades âœ“
In Guyana: Plan (maybe) â†’ Build â†’ Celebrate â†’ Break â†’ Act surprised â†’ Repeat ğŸ”„
Context: This is the same country that built Heroes Highway with concrete in December 2023, then announced an asphalt overlay in January 2025 (13 months later). The highway that was supposed to last generations needs repairs before it hits two years old.
ğŸ“ 18 SCHOOLS TO BE COMMISSIONED (ELECTION YEAR SPECIAL!) ğŸ« SCHOOL ANNOUNCEMENT PATTERN ğŸ«
âœ“ Years 1-4: Announce, construct, delay, delay again
â†’ Year 5 (Election Year): LOOK! 18 SCHOOLS AT ONCE!
Government commissioning 18 schools by Q1 2026. Important questions remain unanswered: Who’s teaching? Where’s the Wi-Fi coming from? Do the bathrooms work?
The Digital School Achievement: Successfully held its first lesson where students logged into Zoom without the internet dying. The bar is underground, but we cleared it!
ğŸ“Š GRA DISCOVERS INTERNAL CONSPIRACY â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
IRONY LEVEL: MAXIMUM âš ï¸ â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
â†’ Tax Collectors: Helping people NOT pay taxes
â†’ Government: *Shocked Pikachu face*
GRA uncovered a coordinated internal conspiracy. People at the tax-collecting agency were actively helping people avoid paying taxes. The agency designed to collect revenue was facilitating revenue loss. You can’t make this up.
ğŸ† YOUR FRIDAY RECAP ğŸ“š WHAT WE LEARNED:
Guyana is America's new deportee storage facility The Mohameds discovered another appeal option Bridges are temporary suggestions, not permanent infrastructure 18 schools materialize during election year Working internet = national achievement unlocked Tax collectors need tax collectors to watch them ğŸ”® WEEKEND FORECAST:
â˜ï¸ 100% chance of Mohamed updates
ğŸŒ§ï¸ 90% chance of infrastructure excuses
â›ˆï¸ 80% chance of Venezuela confusion
ğŸŒ©ï¸ 60% chance your bridge is cracking
âš¡ 50% chance your internet works
The Daily Laugh: Your daily dose of “wait, that actually happened?” ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾
All stories real. All outrage justified. All satire absolutely necessary.

content:
ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾ THE DAILY LAUGH ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¾Your 5-Minute Guyana News Digest
Sponsored by: Strong Coffee & Questionable Life Choices
ğŸ­ BREAKING: MADURO GETS THE ULTIMATE SURPRISE PARTY ğŸ“Š QUICK STATS:
Operation Speed: Faster than DoorDash
Caribbean Group Chat Status: ğŸ”¥ Going Wild
Guyana's Official Response: Diplomatically ThrilledY’all, the Americans just Uber-kidnapped an entire president. Not even DoorDash is that efficient.
What Happened: Trump sent the boys to Venezuela like it was a Black Friday sale at Courts. Operation resulted in NicolÃ¡s Maduro getting the express trip to New York he DEFINITELY didn’t book on Travelocity.
ğŸ—£ï¸ WHAT THE PAPERS SAID:
ğŸ“° Stabroek News: "We must consider the geopolitical implications..."
ğŸ“° Kaieteur News: "MADURO GRABBED! WE BEEN TELLING Y'ALL!"
ğŸ“° Chronicle: "President Ali Says Things. Government Does Stuff. Everything Fine."
ğŸ“° Guyana Times: "Anyway, here's a story about motorsports and a beauty pageant."
Guyana’s Response: President Ali is doing that Caribbean thing where you’re simultaneously thrilled, terrified, and trying not to laugh. He commended Trump which is like thanking the bouncer for removing your drunk ex from the party.
Real Talk: Guyana just watched its annoying neighbor get arrested on COPS: International Edition. Live. In real time. While the whole Caribbean group chat was going absolutely wild.
The Awkward Part: Now Guyana has to pretend they’re not THRILLED about this. Because diplomacy. And international relations. And the fact that they share a border with a country that just got regime-changed via air strike.
ğŸ’° THE MOHAMEDS: AMERICA’S MOST WANTED âš–ï¸ THE MOHAMED LEGAL SAGA TRACKER âš–ï¸
Legal Strategies Used: 80%Courts Appealed To: ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ›ï¸ğŸ›ï¸ (and counting)
Florida's Response: *uses full name*
This father-son duo is having the kind of week that makes you reconsider all your life choices.
The Situation: The Mohameds are fighting extradition to Florida harder than your auntie fights for the last piece of black cake at Christmas. Their legal strategy appears to be “The Mohameds are NOT going anywhere!” which is NOT how extradition treaties work.
BREAKING NEWS TICKER
ğŸš¨ Court says NO â†’ Lawyers say APPEAL â†’ Repeat Loop #4 ğŸš¨
Their Lawyers Said: “We are confident this case will be dismissed.”
The Court Said: “No.”
Their Lawyers Said: “Well, we’re appealing.”
Everyone Else: “Of course you are.”
Kaieteur’s Coverage: They’ve written more about the Mohameds than the Mohameds’ mothers did in baby books. At this point, Kaieteur News could publish a Mohameds encyclopedia.
The Pattern: Court says yes, Lawyers say no, Appeal filed, Repeat. They’re currently on loop 4.
Florida’s Patience Level: Approaching zero. The US Attorney’s office has started sending strongly worded letters, which in legal terms is like your mom using your full name.
ğŸ›£ï¸ HEROES HIGHWAY: A LOVE STORY GONE WRONG âš ï¸ INFRASTRUCTURE SPEED-RUN CHALLENGE âš ï¸
Built:December 2023 (concrete)Lasted:13 MONTHSExpected Lifespan:20-30 yearsAchievement:World Record FailureDecember 2023: Government unveils shiny new concrete highway
January 2025: Ministry announces asphalt overlay project
Let’s Do The Math: That’s 13 months. The highway lasted about as long as a New Year’s resolution.
Translation: They built a highway with concrete. Premium concrete. It lasted barely over a year. Now they want to cover it with asphalt.
ğŸ“‹ HOW INFRASTRUCTURE WORKS:
Elsewhere: Plan â†’ Build â†’ Maintain â†’ Use for decades âœ“
In Guyana: Plan (maybe) â†’ Build â†’ Celebrate â†’ Break â†’ Act surprised â†’ Announce solutions â†’ Repeat ğŸ”„
This is like:
Buying a Tesla and gluing a bicycle on top Ordering premium steak and covering it with ketchup Building a mansion and putting up wallpaper to hide the cracks Stabroek News (Being Polite): “Questions have been raised about whether sound decisions are being made…”
Us (Not Being Polite): Y’ALL BUILT A HIGHWAY WRONG.
What Actually Happened: Someone made a decision. That decision was wrong. That wrongness cost millions. Now another decision will cost more millions to fix the first wrong decision.
Engineering 101: Concrete highways should last 20-30 years. Heroes Highway speedran that timeline like it was going for a world record.
ğŸ“± DIGITAL SCHOOL: WHEN ZOOM FINALLY CAME TO GUYANA ğŸ“ DIGITAL SCHOOL SUCCESS METRICS ğŸ“
âœ“ Students logged into Zoomâœ“ Internet didn't crashâœ“ Teachers troubleshot for 45 minutesâœ“ Taught for 10 minutesâ†’ ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED!The Ministry of Education is THRILLED to announce that students successfully… logged into Zoom.
Let That Sink In: The achievement isn’t the lesson. The achievement isn’t the teaching. The achievement is that THE INTERNET DIDN’T CRASH.
Participating Schools: Dora Secondary, St. Cuthbert’s Secondary, Kwakwani Secondary, Linden Foundation Secondary, Anna Regina Secondary.
ğŸ† ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED:
Guyana Internet Works For 20 Minutes!
Parent’s Perspective: “So my data plan is now a school supply?”
Teacher’s Perspective: “I spent 45 minutes troubleshooting connectivity and 10 minutes teaching.”
Government’s Perspective: “DIGITAL TRANSFORMATION! PROGRESS!”
Reality Check: Other countries have been doing this since 2020. We’re celebrating in 2026 that we successfully used Zoom. The app your grandmother figured out during COVID.
ğŸŒ¾ RICE FARMERS GET 2.1 BILLION ğŸ’¸ THE FLOOD RELIEF CYCLE ğŸ’¸
1ï¸âƒ£ Build drainage systems
2ï¸âƒ£ Don't maintain them
3ï¸âƒ£ Flooding happens
4ï¸âƒ£ Act surprised
5ï¸âƒ£ Give out money
6ï¸âƒ£ Repeat next year ğŸ”„
Agriculture Minister Mustapha is touring the country handing out checks like Oprah’s Guyanese cousin.
The Official Story: “Government assistance initiative”
The Real Story: “Remember when y’all flooded twice? Here’s some money. Sorry about that.”
Black Bush Polder Residents: “Our crops are still underwater but okay, thanks.”
May 2024: Flooding
December 2024: More flooding
January 2025: Money for the flooding
What Farmers Actually Need: Working drainage, flood prevention, infrastructure maintenance, maybe some oil money?
What Farmers Got: Checks after damage is done, photo op with minister, promises of improvement.
ğŸ¯ YOUR DAILY RECAP ğŸ“ WHAT WE LEARNED:
Trump moves faster than Guyana contractorsThe Mohameds discovered infinite appeals glitchConcrete highways are temporaryWorking Wi-Fi is a national achievementFlood relief works better as preventionğŸ”® TOMORROW'S FORECAST:
â˜ï¸ 100% chance of Mohamed headlines
ğŸŒ§ï¸ 80% chance of ministry denials
â›ˆï¸ 60% chance of infrastructure announcements
ğŸŒ©ï¸ 40% chance infrastructure breaks within a year
This is satirical commentary protected under Guyana's fair use provisions. See our Legal Disclaimer.
